wrap.p: &xist; is an extensible &html;/&xml; generator written in Python. It was developed as a replacement for an &html; preprocessor named HSC and borrows some features and ideas from it. It also borrows the basic ideas (&xml;/&html; elements as Python objects) from HTMLgen or HyperText.
(If you're impatient, there's also a list of examples that shows what can be done with &xist;.)

section.p: &xist; can be used as a compiler that reads an input &xml; file and generates a transformed output file, or it could be used for generating &xml; dynamically inside a web server (but note that handling object trees is slower than simply sending string fragments). In either case generating the final &html; or &xml; output requires the following three steps:

ul.li: Generating a source &xml; tree: This can be done either by parsing an &xml; file, or by directly constructing the tree — as HTMLgen and HyperText do — as a tree of Python objects. &xist; provides a very natural and pythonic &api; for that.

Converting the source tree into a target tree: This target tree can be a &html; tree or a &svg; tree or XSL-FO tree or any other &xml; tree you like. Every node class provides a convert method for performing this conversion. For your own &xml; element types you have to define your own element classes and implement an appropriate convert method. This is possible for processing instructions and entity references too.

Publishing the target tree: For generating the final output a Publisher object is used that generates the encoded byte string fragments that can be written to an output stream (or yielded from a WSGI application, etc.).

section.p: Like any other &xml; tree &api;, &xist; provides the usual classes:

ul.li: Frag for document fragments, (a Frag object is simply a list of nodes);
DocType for document type declarations (e.g. <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC ...>).

section.p: &xist; works somewhat different from a normal &dom; &api;. Instead of only one element class, &xist; has one class for every element type. All the elements from different &xml; vocabularies known to &xist; are defined in modules in the ll.xist.ns subpackage. (Of course it's possible to define additional element classes for your own &xml; vocabulary). The definition of &html; can be found in ll.xist.ns.html for example.
Every element class has a constructor of the form:

Positional arguments (i.e. items in content) will be the child nodes of the element node. Keyword arguments will be attributes. You can pass most of Python's builtin types to such a constructor. Strings (str and unicode) and integers will be automatically converted to Text objects. Constructing an &html; element works like this:

example.prog:
from ll.xist.ns import html
node = html.div( "Hello ", html.a("Python", href="http://www.python.org/"), " world!" )

section.p: For attribute names that collide with Python keywords or are not legal identifiers (most notably class in &html;) the attribute name must be slightly modified, so that it's a legal Python identifier (for class an underscore is appended):

example.prog: node = html.div( "Hello world!", class_="greeting" )

section.p: (Don't worry: This modified attribute name will be mapped to the real official attribute name once the output is generated.)
You can pass attributes as a dictionary too:

example.prog: node = html.div( "Hello world!", dict(class_="greeting", id=42, title="Greet the world") )

section.p: Furthermore it's possible to use with blocks to construct &xist; trees. Inside a with block the unary + operator or the add function can be used to add nodes or attributes to the current level of the tree:

example.prog: with xsc.build(): with html.div(class_="quote") as node: with html.h1("Confucius (551-479 BC)"): xsc.add(class_="author") with html.ol(): +html.li("I hear and I forget.") +html.li("I see and I believe.") +html.li("I do and I understand.")

section.p: xsc.build must be used as the top level with block, so that &xist; knows what to do with the nodes inside the block.
&xml; trees can also be generated by parsing &xml; files. For this the module ll.xist.parsers provides several functions:

dl.dd: Parse the string data into an &xist; tree.
Parse the input from the iterable iterable (which must produce the input in chunks of bytes) into an &xist; tree.
Parse &xml; from the stream stream into an &xist; tree.
Parse &xml; input from the file named filename.

dt.lit: parseurl(name, base=None, encoding=None, bufsize=8192, headers=None, data=None, **builderargs)

dl.dd: Parse &xml; input from the &url; name into an &xist; tree.
Parse &xml; input from the object tree which must support the ElementTree &api;.

section.p: For example, parsing a string can be done like this:

example.prog:
from ll.xist import parsers from ll.xist.ns import html node = parsers.parsestring("

Hello Python world!

")

section.p: For further info about the arguments to the parsing functions, see the documentation for ll.xist.parsers.Builder.

section.h: Defining new elements and converting &xml; trees
section.p: To be able to parse an &xml; file, you have to provide an element class for every element type that appears in the file. These classes either come from modules provided by &xist; or you can define your own. Defining your own element class for an element named cool works like this:

You have to derive your new class from xsc.Element. The name of the class will be the element name. For element type names that are invalid Python identifiers, you can use the class attribute xmlname in the element class to overwrite the element name.

To be able to convert an element of this type to a new &xml; tree (probably &html; in most cases), you have to implement the convert method. In this method you can build a new &xml; tree from the content and attributes of the object.
Using this new element is simple

example.tty: >>> node = cool("Python") >>> print node.conv().bytes() Python is cool!

section.p: conv simply calls convert with a default converter argument. We'll come to converters in a minute. bytes is a method that converts the node to a byte string. This method will be explained when we discuss the publishing interface.

Note that it is vital for your own convert methods that you recursively call convert on your own content, because otherwise some unconverted nodes might remain in the tree. Let's define a new element:
Now we can do the following:
section.tty: >>> node = cool(python()) >>> print node.conv().bytes() Python is cool!
section.p: But if we forget to call convert for our own content, i.e. if the element cool was written like this:
we would get:
section.prog: >>> node = cool(python()) >>> print node.conv().bytes() is cool!
section.p: Furthermore convert should never modify , because convert might be called multiple times for the same node.

conv is a convenience method that creates a default converter for you and calls convert. This converter is created once and is passed to all convert calls. It is used to store parameters for the conversion process and it allows convert methods to store additional information, so that it is available elsewhere during the conversion process. You can also call convert yourself, which would look like this:
section.prog:
from ll.xist import converters from ll.xist.ns import html
node = cool(python()) node = node.convert(converters.Converter())
section.p: You can pass the following arguments to the Converter constructor:

dl.dd: mode (which defaults to None) works the same way as modes in &xslt;. You can use this for implementing different conversion modes.

stage (which defaults to "deliver") allows you to implement multi stage conversion: Suppose that you want to deliver a dynamically constructed web page with &xist; that contains results from a database query and the current time. The data in the database changes infrequently, so it doesn't make sense to do the query on every request. The query is done every few minutes and the resulting &html; tree is stored in the servlet (using any of the available Python servlet technologies). For this conversion the stage would be "cache" and your database &xml; element would do the query when stage=="cache". Your time display element would do the conversion when stage=="deliver" and simply returns itself when stage=="cache", so it would still be part of the cached &xml; tree and would be converted to &html; on every request.
target (which defaults to ll.xist.ns.html) specifies what the output should be. Values must be namespace subclasses (see below for an explanation of namespaces).

dd.p: lang (which defaults to None) is the language in which the result tree should be. This can be used in the convert method to implement different conversions for different languages, e.g.:

section.p: Additional arguments are passed when a converter is created in the context of a make script.
Setting and accessing the attributes of an element works either via a dictionary interface or by accessing the &xml; attributes as Python attributes of the elements attrs attribute:

example.tty:
>>> node = html.a(u"Python", href=u"http://www.python.org/") >>> print node[u"href"].bytes() href="http://www.python.org/" >>> del node.attrs.href >>> print node[u"href"].bytes()
>>> node[u"href"] = u"http://www.python.org" >>> print node.attrs.href.bytes() href="http://www.python.org/"

section.p: All attribute values are instances of subclasses of the class Attr. Available subclasses are:

ul.li: BoolAttr, for boolean attributes (for such an attribute only its presence is important, it's value will always be the same as the attribute name when publishing);

section.p: IntAttr and ColorAttr mostly serve as documentation of the attributes purpose. Both classes have no added functionality.
Attr itself is derived from Frag so it is possible to use all the sequence methods on an attribute.
Unset attributes will be treated like empty ones so the following is possible:

example.prog: del node["spam"] node["spam"].append("ham")

section.p: This also means that after del node["spam"][:] the attribute will be empty again and will be considered to be unset. Such attributes will be skipped when publishing.
The main purpose of this is to allow you to construct values conditionally and then use those values as attribute values:
In 50% of the cases the generated div element will not have a class attribute.

When you define a new element you have to specify the attributes allowed for this element. For this use the class attribute Attrs (which must be a class derived from xsc.Element.Attrs) and define the attributes by deriving them from one of the existing attribute classes. We could extend our example element in the following way:
and use it like this:
section.tty: >>> node = cool(python(), adj=u"totally") >>> node.conv().bytes() Python is totally cool!

section.p: It is possible to define default values for attributes via the class attribute default:
Now if we instantiate the class without specifying adj we'll get the default:

example.tty: >>> node = cool(python()) >>> print node.conv().bytes() Python is absolutely cool!

section.p: If we want a cool instance without an adj attribute, we can pass None as the attribute value:

example.tty: >>> node = cool(python(), adj=None) >>> print node.conv().bytes() Python is cool!

section.p: It's possible to specify that an attribute has a fixed set of allowed values. This can be done with the class attribute values. We could extend our example to look like this:
These values won't be checked when we create our cool instance. Only when this node is parsed from a file will the warning be issued:
section.tty: >>> s = '<cool adj="pretty"><python/></cool>' >>> node = parsers.parsestring(s) /Users/walter/checkouts/LivingLogic.Python.xist/src/ll/xist/xsc.py:2006: \ IllegalAttrValueWarning: Attribute value u'pretty' not allowed for __main__:cool.Attrs.adj warnings.warn(IllegalAttrValueWarning(self))
section.p: The warning will also be issued if we publish such a node, but note that for warnings Python's warning framework is used, so the warning will be printed only once (but of course you can change that with warnings.filterwarnings):
section.tty: >>> node = cool(python(), adj=u"pretty") >>> print node.bytes() /Users/walter/checkouts/LivingLogic.Python.xist/src/ll/xist/xsc.py:2006: \ IllegalAttrValueWarning: Attribute value u'pretty' not allowed for __main__:cool.Attrs.adj warnings.warn(IllegalAttrValueWarning(self)) <cool adj="very"><python /></cool>

section.p: Finally it's possible to specify that an attribute is required. This again will only be checked when parsing or publishing. To specify that an attribute is required simply add the class attribute required with the value True. The attribute alt of the class ll.xist.ns.html.img is such an attribute, so we'll get:

example.tty: >>> from ll.xist.ns import html >>> node = html.img(src="eggs.png") >>> print node.bytes() /home/walter/pythonroot/ll/xist/xsc.py:2046: \ RequiredAttrMissingWarning: Required attribute 'alt' missing in ll.xist.ns.html:img.Attrs. warnings.warn(errors.RequiredAttrMissingWarning(self, attrs.keys()))

section.p: Now that you've defined your own elements, you have to tell the parser about them, so they can be instantiated when a file is parsed. First you have to assign an &xml; namespace to these classes. This is done by setting the class attribute xmlns to the namespace name:
When parsing the parser fetches the classes it uses from a Pool object. We can put our two classes into a pool like this:

example.prog: pool = xsc.Pool(python, cool)

section.p: It's also possible to register the element classes in a pool directly at class construction time via a with block like this:

example.h: Populating a pool with a with block

section.p: Now you can use this pool for parsing:

example.prog:
s = '<cool xmlns="http://xmlns.example.org/foo"><python/></cool>'
node = parsers.parsestring(s, pool=pool)

section.p: It's also possible to call the parsing function with a predefined mapping between namespace names and namespace prefixes:

example.prog:
s = '<cool><python/></cool>'
node = parsers.parsestring(s, pool=pool, prefixes={None: "http://xmlns.example.org/foo"})

section.p: If you have many elements, registering them in a pool becomes cumbersome. In this case you can put your element classes into a module and then register the module in the pool:

example.prog:
import foo_xmlns # This is the module containing the element classes
pool = xsc.Pool(foo_xmlns)

section.p: You can define global attributes belonging to a certain namespace by defining a global Attrs class and giving each attribute a namespace name via xmlns:
To make this global attribute know to the parsing, you simply can put the Attrs in the pool used for parsing.
Setting and accessing such an attribute can be done by using the attribute class instead of the attribute name like this:
section.tty: >>> from ll.xist.ns import html >>> node = html.div(u"foo", {Attrs.foo: u"bar") >>> str(node[Attrs.foo]) 'bar'
section.p: An alternate way of specifying a global attribute in a constructor looks like this:
section.tty: >>> from ll.xist.ns import html >>> node = html.div(u"foo", Attrs(foo=u"baz")) >>> str(node[Attrs.foo]) 'baz'

section.p: In the same way as defining new element types, you can define new entities. The following example is from the module ll.xist.ns.abbr:
You can use this entity in your &xml; files like this:

example.prog: <cool adj="very">&html;</cool>

section.p: Defining processing instructions works just like elements and entities. Derive a new class from ll.xist.xsc.ProcInst and implement convert. The following example implements a processing instruction that returns an uppercase version of its content as a text node.
It can be used in an &xml; file like this:

example.h: Using the newly defined processing instruction
example.prog: <cool><?upper foo?></cool>

section.p: There are namespaces containing processing instruction classes that don't provide a convert method. These processing instruction objects will then be published as &xml; processing instructions. One example is the namespace ll.xist.ns.php.

Other namespaces (like ll.xist.ns.jsp) contain processing instruction classes, but they will be published in a different (not &xml; compatible) format. For example ll.xist.ns.jsp.expression("foo") will be published as <%= foo>.

After creating the &xml; tree and converting the tree into its final output form, you have to write the resulting tree to a file. This can be done with the publishing &api;. Three methods that use the publishing &api; are iterbytes, bytes and write. iterbytes is a generator that will yield the complete 8-bit &xml; string in fragments. bytes returns the complete 8-bit &xml; string.
Writing a node to a file can be done with the method write:
All these methods use the method publish internally. publish gets passed an instance of ll.xist.publisher.Publisher.

You can specify the encoding with the parameter encoding (with the encoding specified in an &xml; declaration being the default, if there is no such declaration "utf-8" is used). Unencodable characters will be escaped with character references when possible (i.e. inside text nodes, for comments or processing instructions you'll get an exception):
section.tty: >>> from ll.xist import xsc >>> from ll.xist.ns import html >>> s = u"A\e4\u03a9\u8a9e" >>> node = html.div(s) >>> print node.bytes(encoding="ascii") <div>AäΩ語> >>> print node.bytes(encoding="iso-8859-1") <div>AäΩ語> >>> print xsc.Comment(s).bytes(encoding="ascii") Traceback (most recent call last): ... File "/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.5/lib/python2.5/encodings/ascii.py", line 22, in encode return codecs.ascii_encode(input, self.errors)[0] UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in position 4-5: ordinal not in range(128)
section.p: When you include an &xml; header or an &html; meta header, &xist; will automatically insert the correct encoding when publishing:
section.tty: >>> from ll.xist import xsc >>> from ll.xist.ns import xml, meta >>> e = xsc.Frag(xml.XML(), u"\n", meta.contenttype()) >>> print e.conv().bytes(encoding="iso-8859-15") <?xml version='1.0' encoding='iso-8859-15'?> <meta content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-15" http-equiv="Content-Type" />

This gives &html; compatible &xhtml;. Elements with an empty content model will be published like this:

section.p: By default &xist; doesn't output any namespace declarations. The simplest way to change that, is to pass True for the prefixdefault argument when publishing:

example.prog:
from ll.xist.ns import html
e = html.html( html.head( html.title("The page") ), html.body( html.h1("The header"), html.p("The content") ) )
print e.bytes(prefixdefault=True)

section.p: Using True allows &xist; to choose its own prefixes. The code above will output (rewrapped for clarity):
You can also use a fixed prefix:
This will output (again rewrapped):
If you want the empty prefix you can use None:
This will output (again rewrapped):

When elements from more than one namespace are present in the tree, prefixdefault is unreliable. The first namespace encountered will get the prefix specified by prefixdefault, all others will get a different prefix. &xist; will never use the same prefix for different namespaces. &xist; will also refuse to use an empty prefix for global attributes:

example.prog:
from ll.xist import xsc from ll.xist.ns import html, xlink
with xsc.build(): with html.html() as e: with html.head(): +html.title("The page") with html.body(): +html.h1("The header"), with html.p(): +xsc.Text("The "), +html.a( "Python", xlink.Attrs( href="http://www.python.org/", title="Python", type="simple" ), href="http://www.python.org/") +xsc.Text(" homepage")
print e.bytes(prefixdefault=None)

section.p: This will output:
section.prog:
The page

The header

The Python homepage
